posts.name: Daniel
posts.cooked: So I am encountering issues with my endmills being broken and I don’t know why because this has never happened in the past. So I have a 4mm endmill and after I finish a few parts they snap inside the collet. It doesn’t break tip or anything but it just breaks on the inside. I know that I provide enough coolant. Maybe this could be an issue on how far I stick the endmill in the collet??? Does anyone have an explanation for this?

posts.name: wesbass23
posts.cooked: I don’t have a direct answer to this yet, not sure I will be able to help but I know people more knowledgeable than me are likely going to want more info about your setup (pictures if possible) and info about feeds/speeds/materials etc.

posts.name: Daniel
posts.cooked: Alright I will get this information to you guys soon

posts.name: kgzak
posts.cooked:
Collet might be bad. Or is there stuff in the collet/taper?

We had a bad collet that would break bits. Swapped it out and it worked much better.

posts.name: pryland
posts.cooked: Wrong size collet being tightened too much?  If wrong feed etc., bit would snap below collet. Collets are rated for Maximum size.  A 4mm collet would handle 3mm-4mm bits. A 1/8" collet would handle a max size of 3.175mm.  Hope this helps.

posts.name: Daniel
posts.cooked:
Would tightening too much really cause the issue? And also just checked the collet is the right size. We also have a chatter issue so this is why we do tighten it a lot.

To note, the end mill seems to be cracking right above the point of contact between the collet and the end mill on the inside. image 1920×2560 198 KB

image 1920×2560 198 KB

image 1920×2560 198 KB

posts.name: Jon K.
posts.cooked:
Potentially. Chatter isn’t necessarily caused by collet tightness either. Overtightening a collet can actually cause fatigue on your collet and cause your chatter because the collet can no longer hold it correctly. Try replacing your collet. The general rule I give my staff is hand tight and then 1/8 turn for an ER32 collet on our router. We also use 1/4" shank tools for almost everything and the cutting edge necks down to the correct diameter making life easy for collet replacements. Typically we keep the shank fully inside the collet, and the cutting edge down below if possible or needed, but not always.

What is your Depth of Cut? What is your spindle speed? Feed rate? Material type? Material thickness? How much of your bit is exposed on the other side? How much of that is cutting edge vs shank? What’s your cutting edge length vs the material thickness? It could be an issue where you just have too much bit and don’t need it, and the router is going to fast, and it just causes it to snap.

Also check for random spindle stop codes M5 or M05 depending on what your CAM program outputs. I have seen random M5 codes get added in the middle of a program someone else wrote, and it took 3 snapped bits before we found the problem in his CAM settings where it called for a “forced tool change” which put in errant M5 codes to stop the spindle.

However, I actually managed to get 1/4" bits to snap the other day because the material between parts was flopping around too much on the router.

posts.name: pryland
posts.cooked: Material interactions with the bit will cause it to snap below the collet.   Those bits are probably carbide, which are brittle.  You can drop one on concrete and break it.  I really do believe there is a problem with the collet . A good collet should apply pressure evenly around the bit.  It is possible there is something wrong with the collet and as you apply torque it is creating a stress fracture.   IMO Replace the collet.

posts.name: Jon K.
posts.cooked: Depending on how they put the bit in, it could be below or above the collet line. I’ve seen it happen in both places, using carbide bits, almost never in the shank though.

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: How much is the end mill sticking out of the collet and how deep are you going into the material? A long stick out will cause the end mill to flex when applying a side load on it and cause it to snap off. It can usually be remedied by slowing the feed rate down.

posts.name: D_Price (1708 Co-Lead Mentor)
posts.cooked: Also, on top of all the other information provided, please verify your speeds and feeds especially if you are running too slow and taking too many chips you’ll explode a bit, albeit also the same will happen if you run too fast.

posts.name: Mr. Mike
posts.cooked:
I will lay odds that it is a bad collet. When you put in a new end mill, does it slide smoothly in all of the way? Or does it slide in most of the way then stops short of going all of the way through? If someone has put an end mill in short and over tightened it their will be a step in the  back of the collet. When an end mill is pushed past the step it will create a stress riser when the tool holder is tightened. Add chatter and the tool will fracture.

Please post your findings

Mr. Mike

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: One of the best things you can do is film it running with sound. Take a static shot of it spinning up and down, take a shot of it making a part.

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: I kinda assume you mean cnc router? This may seem silly, but make sure the fixture holding the actual router tool is tight. We had an issue that made me think I wasn’t tightening our collet enough because we were getting a lot of chatter. This also led to a few broken end mills. When I over tightened it, some of the chatter went away so I thought that was it. Come to find out after breaking the router tool, it was being held loose. New router, held it tight, don’t need to crank on the collet like hell anymore, and I’m getting clean smooth cuts.

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
OP’s collet looks like what I’d expect for a ~1/4" tool. You’ll almost always find  that internal backside relief on small ID ER32 and larger collets.

I have a $500 Regofix ER-32 collet set in front of me right now that looks exactly the same on a 1/4" collet.

posts.name: pryland
posts.cooked: Just occurred to me, the collets are suppose to snap into the nut.  Make sure that the collet is actually seated in the nut before tightening.  You should be able to hold the nut upside down and collet not fall out.  I’m not sure of your experience, but a common beginner mistake is to place the collet on the spindle and then place the nut on and tighten.
